# Contributing to Expert-Driven Development (EDD) Training

Welcome, and thank you for your interest in contributing to the Expert-Driven Development Training repository. This project provides open-source training materials for Department of War personnel on AI-assisted development methodologies. Your contributions help improve the quality and breadth of these resources for service members across the DoW.

## Table of Contents

- [Getting Started](#getting-started)
- [Submitting Issues](#submitting-issues)
- [Submitting Pull Requests](#submitting-pull-requests)
- [Content Guidelines](#content-guidelines)
- [Style Guidelines](#style-guidelines)
- [Branch Naming Convention](#branch-naming-convention)
- [Review Process](#review-process)
- [Contact](#contact)

## Getting Started

1. Fork this repository to your own GitHub account.
2. Clone your fork locally.
3. Create a new branch following the [branch naming convention](#branch-naming-convention).
4. Make your changes.
5. Push your branch and open a pull request.

## Submitting Issues

We use GitHub Issues to track bugs, content requests, and general feedback. Please use the appropriate issue template when opening a new issue:

- **Bug Report** -- for broken links, formatting issues, or inaccurate content.
- **Content Request** -- for requesting new training modules, examples, or templates.
- **Feedback** -- for general feedback, suggestions, or questions.

Issue templates are available when you create a new issue. Please fill out all required fields and provide as much detail as possible to help maintainers understand and address your submission.

## Submitting Pull Requests

1. Ensure your changes align with the [content guidelines](#content-guidelines) and [style guidelines](#style-guidelines) below.
2. Fill out the pull request template completely, including the security and compliance checklist.
3. Reference any related issues in your pull request description (e.g., `Closes #12`).
4. Ensure your branch is up to date with the `main` branch before submitting.
5. All pull requests will be reviewed by a maintainer before merging. Be prepared to address feedback or requested changes.

## Content Guidelines

All content in this repository must comply with the following requirements:

- **UNCLASSIFIED only.** All materials must be UNCLASSIFIED and suitable for public release. Do not commit any classified, CUI, FOUO, or export-controlled information.
- **No PII.** Do not include real names, DoW ID numbers, Social Security Numbers, personal email addresses, phone numbers, or any other personally identifiable information.
- **No real operational data.** Do not reference real operations, unit-specific procedures, or operationally sensitive material.
- **Fictional names and data only.** All examples, scenarios, and sample data must use fictional names, units, and information.
- **Verify before committing.** Contributors are responsible for reviewing their own content to confirm it is UNCLASSIFIED and free of prohibited information before committing.

For full details, see the [Security Policy](../SECURITY.md).

## Style Guidelines

- Maintain a **professional tone** appropriate for a military and government audience.
- Write clearly and concisely. Avoid slang, colloquialisms, and overly casual language.
- Use proper grammar, spelling, and punctuation.
- Structure documents with clear headings, lists, and sections for readability.
- When referencing tools, technologies, or processes, provide enough context for readers who may be unfamiliar.
- Use Markdown formatting consistently across all documents.

## Branch Naming Convention

Use the following naming conventions when creating branches:

| Branch Type            | Format                | Example                      |
|------------------------|-----------------------|------------------------------|
| New feature            | `feature/description` | `feature/add-prompt-module`  |
| Bug fix or correction  | `fix/description`     | `fix/broken-link-lesson-3`   |

Keep branch names lowercase, concise, and descriptive. Use hyphens to separate words.

## Review Process

- All pull requests require review and approval by at least one project maintainer before merging.
- Maintainers will review for content accuracy, compliance with security and content guidelines, adherence to style guidelines, and overall quality.
- Contributors may be asked to revise their submissions based on review feedback.
- Do not merge your own pull requests without maintainer approval.
